DOC.HEAD: Popular TV Program Disappears From Screen
DOC.TEXT: State-run radio and TV dropped without explanation last week's broadcast of the country's most popular program, whose controversial and free-wheeling shows have been a lightning rod for conservative criticism. One youth newspaper, Moskovsky Komsomolets, complained Saturday that the decision to pull the two-hour ``Vzglad'' program from the Friday night schedule smacked of the heavy-handed pre-glasnost censorship of the media _ ``in a word, to spit on public opinion and forget about it.'' Alexander Lyubimov, one of the creators of ``Vzglad,'' or View, said by telephone that the ``directors of Gostelradio made a decision to reduce the amount of political programming on the eve of the New Year.'' He refused to comment further on the decision. ``Vzglad'' has used the freer atmosphere of glasnost to tackle touchy subjects. In spring, members of the Communist Party Central Committee expressed outrage when stage director Mark Zakharov suggested on the program that Lenin's body be removed from display in a mausoleum on Red Square and buried. Since then, the idea has gained some public support among Soviet intellectuals. Boris Nepomnyashchy, director of the nationwide radio network Mayak that is another branch of the state radio and TV complex, told listeners during a live call-in program Saturday that the ``Vzglad'' program for Friday was not ready and would be shown shortly after the New Year's holiday, his secretary said. Instead of ``Vzglad,'' viewers were shown a program dedicated to the work of Leningrad theater director Igor Vladimirov. Television sources said the decision to pull the Friday edition of ``Vzglad'' was made Thursday. Only the Communist Party daily Pravda was able to make a last-minute change in its program listing. Sources close to ``Vzglad'' said the program would be back on the air Jan. 5 but that TV schedules in the future would list only ``youth program'' in their late evening time slot, allowing different programming to be substituted at the last minute. They denied Moskovsky Komsomolets' report that plainclothes men had entered the program's studios and seized all copies of the intended program, which the newspaper reported was to be a parody of the stodgy nightly TV news program ``Vremya.'' The sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the program was to air a piece on human rights activist Andrei D. Sakharov who died Dec. 14, and a historical review of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reform effort. Soviet media have come under pressure lately from Gorbachev and other officials to narrow the scope of the public debate about the Soviet past and instead try to build a consensus on how to solve difficult social and economic problems. But one ``Vzglad'' source speculated that the cancellation of the program was instigated by Gorbachev's conservative foes to make the Soviet leader look bad before a public that would assume the program only could be canceled on his authority. Moskovsky Komsomolets also claimed that a ``black list'' of rock groups that should not be shown on Soviet TV was circulating at the state television studios.
